intro: Siphocampylus incanus, commonly known as the hairy leaf tamarisk, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Fabaceae, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and small, pea-like flowers. The plant has compound leaves with a hairy texture, which helps reduce water loss in arid environments. It produces pods that contain seeds, and it is often found in dry, sandy soils along riverbanks and disturbed areas. Siphocampylus incanus is adapted to thrive in semi-desert and coastal regions, showcasing its resilience to harsh conditions.
